Service_name: Service Dogs - Veteran Assistance (Duo Dogs, Inc.)
Eligibility: ['The applicant(s) must be able to care for and cover the cost of the dog’s basic daily needs, veterinary needs and extended needs including exercise and enrichment.', 'All applicants must have the cognitive ability and working memory necessary to coordinate care for the dog, learn and implement a complex sequence of commands paired with physical redirection.', 'Applicants for Assistance Dogs must have received documentation of diagnosis of a disability/disabling condition at least one year prior to application.', 'We require all applicants and those residing in their households aged 18+ to complete a background check.']
Description: Duo Dogs provides professional trained dogs assistance dogs to veterans helping them resume an independent lifestyle. Our service dogs help individuals live a more independent, productive life. Service: - Trained service dogService dogs are taught a wide range of commands in order to assist in the activities of daily living and enrich the life of a veteran with a disability, providing a greater sense of independence. All assistance dogs have public access and can accompany their handler in all places of public accommodation. Duo provides constant follow up for the duration of every assistance dog placement, requiring annual client checks and recertification. Duo views every placement as a partnership for as long as the client and dog are a working team.Duo places all of its dogs at no cost to the veteran. The Disabled American Veterans Independence Dog (the DAVID) Fund helps with the application fee and equipment costs associated with a veteran receiving an assistance dog.  If you are in need of an Assistance Dog, please fill out the online application questionnaire to begin the process. All interested individuals must complete an application and upon approval and placement, agree to attend a two-week Team Training in St. Louis to receive their assistance dog.
Coverage: This program covers residents of All US states and territories.

Service_name: Online Support Group (Mommies Enduring Neonatal Death (M.E.N.D.))
Description: The M.E.N.D. Online Nationwide Support Group serves families who do not live near a physical chapter or for those who want to connect between in-person groups. Online groups provide a place for families to connect, share their unique story of loss, and learn to live life without your precious baby.Services provide include:- Online support groupThe online group meets from the comfort of your home through the online platform ZOOM.com on the third Thursday of each month. The facilitator will share login information prior to that month's meeting. If you're joining us for the first time in the online group, please complete a quick questionnaire so we can get to know you.
Coverage: This program covers residents of All US states and territories.

Service_name: Online Support Groups (Pregnancy After Loss Support (PALS))
Eligibility: ['This program serves parents in all stages of pregnancy after loss.']
Description: Pregnancy After Loss Support moderates online support groups on Facebook. These groups encourage peer-to-peer support during the all stages of pregnancy after loss, including trying to conceive, pregnancy, and parenting after loss.This program provides:- Online peer support groupsGroups include:- Pregnancy after loss support group- Trying to conceive after loss support group- Parenting after loss support group- Pregnancy after loss support group for dads- Pregnancy after first trimester loss- Pregnancy after second trimester loss- Pregnancy after third trimester loss- Pregnancy after infant and child death- Pregnancy after TFMR support group- Pregnancy after loss with no living children- Pregnancy after loss of a multiple- Pregnancy after loss family support group - grandparents, parents, and friends- Pregnancy after infertility and loss- New bereaved PALS understands that there are also unique situations that could use extra support, so there are also groups for specific situations, including trimester of loss, no living children, termination for medical reasons, and infertility. PALS also moderate a group for dads and one for grandparents, family, and friends.The Facebook online support groups are closed groups. This means that only people who are members in the groups can see what post or comment. People on the friend’s list may be able to see that they have joined the groups, though, either through the profile or through group recommendations from Facebook. Unfortunately, PALS has no control over those settings.To join a group, visit the Facebook page and select Groups, then select the group they would like to join.
Coverage: This program covers residents of All US states and territories.

Service_name: Service Dogs for Veterans (Dogs For Our Brave (DFOB))
Eligibility: ['Must be a service member or veteran who suffered catastrophic injuries, such as loss of limbs, while in service to our country.', 'Service dogs cannot be placed in a home that has another companion dog or pet.']
Description: Dogs For Our Brave provides service/companion dogs at no cost to service members who have suffered catastrophic injuries, such as loss of limbs while in service to our country. We train our dogs to work specifically for the veteran partner we think will be a good match.  This program provides: - Professionally trained service dogs- Dog training, food, equipment, and veterinary care wherever possibleNo service member is ever charged. All costs are covered by the program.Once your Introduction Form is received, DFOB will review it in its entirety. While you wait for your scheduled interview please email a copy of your DD214 form that includes line 24 character of service. The next step will be to schedule you for a phone interview so we can learn more about you and your needs. We will ask you to share your story of service and your injury/injuries. The process of training a service dog can take up to 18 months.
Coverage: This program covers residents of All US states and territories.

Service_name: Coaching Into Care (US Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) - Veterans Health Administration (VHA))
Main_Services: ['mental health care', 'understand mental health', 'government benefits', 'understand government programs', 'navigating the system', 'support network', 'one-on-one support']
Serving: ['adults', 'young adults', 'seniors', 'national guard', 'veterans', 'families', 'caregivers', 'spouses', 'parents', 'depression', 'brain injury', 'anxiety', 'ptsd', 'all mental health', 'substance dependency']
Eligibility: ['Calling about a Veteran, and caller is trying to help the Veteran access care, especially mental health care.']
Description: Coaching Into Care is a national telephone service of the U.S. Dept. of Veterans Affairs (VA) which aims to educate, support, and empower family members and friends who are seeking care or services for a Veteran. Our goal is to help Veterans, their family members, and other loved ones find the appropriate services at their local VA facilities and/or in their community. We also provide coaching to family and friends of Veterans who see that a Veteran in their life may be having difficulty adjusting to civilian life. Coaching is provided by licensed psychologists or social workers, free-of-charge. Coaching involves helping our callers figure out how to motivate the Veteran to seek treatment. We can help you get information about mental health, services at the VA and tips on how to begin the conversation about treatment with a loved one who is a Veteran.What to expect: When you call Coaching Into Care at 888-823-7458, you will talk with a member of our team who specializes in helping callers determine the best way to help the Veteran they care about and how to navigate the VA system. Our hours of operation are Monday — Friday, from 8 AM to 8 PM (Eastern).Calls with a coach vary in length, but generally take 10 to 30 minutes, depending on the issue. Our work with you may extend for several calls and usually with the same coach.Coaching Into Care takes your privacy, and that of the Veteran, very seriously. We keep all calls confidential, except for cases in which we act to protect the lives of you, the Veteran, or others.
Coverage: This program covers residents of All US states and territories.

Service_name: Journey to Israel (Heroes To Heroes Foundation)
Eligibility: ['American Military Combat Veteran with moral injury.', 'Able to travel overseas.', 'Hold Passport.', 'Commitment to team for one year post trip.']
Description: Heroes to Heroes Journey to Israel is a life-changing journey for combat veterans who are having challenges with moral injury, or having challenges returning to civilian life after their time serving our country. American veterans travel to Israel where they are joined by Israeli peers and this group travels, learns, and explores as a unit.Our program is designed to help our participants:-Develop social and emotional bonds with one another while exploring their spirituality and pushing themselves physicallyHeroes to Heroes requires a one-year commitment to the team. Each team will meet via Skype a minimum of every six (6) weeks post-journey for one year. Each team member is expected to commit to his or her team to support one another and be there for one another to help with transitioning back to civilian life. This is an extremely emotional journey, and the processing post-journey is critical. Team members must work together. All participants are expected to refrain from alcohol and, of course, recreational drugs throughout the journey. Participants must agree to give Heroes to Heroes a $520.00 refundable deposit (refunded on return to US ).The only cost to participants is for a U.S. Passport (must have an expiration date of six months or more post-journey), airfare to meet the team at the U.S. point of departure to Israel (usually either EWR (Newark Liberty, NJ), JFK, or LAX), and money for incidentals such as gifts and souvenirs.
Coverage: This program covers residents of All US states and territories.

Description: The Health & Well Being Program provides youth who are experiencing homelessness or are at risk for homelessness, with clinically and culturally appropriate medical, health, and mental health services. This program includes health education workshops to teach creative and realistic strategies addressing the most common health threats among homeless youth such as partner violence, substance abuse, mental health issues and sexual health issues.Our 13-week Pregnancy and Parenting Group, implemented by a My Friend’s Place Clinical Social Worker and a Clinical Supervisor from Vista Del Mar/HomeSafe, offers family therapy and education covering child development, nursing, available community resources, and literacy for youth who are expecting or parenting.Our intensive Case Management services help youth identify needs and set manageable goals for success. Licensed and Master’s Level clinical case workers conduct crisis interventions, individual, and group therapy sessions to treat mental illness, addiction and social challenges, encouraging youth to practice self-care and recognize the harmful impact of high-risk behaviors. Our Case Managers continually advocate on behalf of the youth by linking them to housing options, negotiating public benefits systems, and building relationships with community agencies to find affordable specialized services when needed.Our Services Include:- Individualized Case Management- Crisis Intervention- Conflict Mediation- Anger Management, Stress Reduction and Coping Skills- Individual, Group and Family Counseling- Medical Clinic including STI and HIV testing (offered by onsite partner)- Substance Abuse Education- Violence Prevention- Health Assessments- Pregnancy & Parenting Program- Advocacy & Case ConsultationFor more information please call us at (323) 908-0011

Service_name: Gang Reduction and Youth Development (GRYD) (El Centro Del Pueblo)
Eligibility: ['This program helps people who are 10 to 15 years old.', 'Eligibility for the prevention program is determined through an interview process.']
Description: El Centro del Pueblo is a community service agency for the purpose of alleviating and mitigating the negative affects of gang violence. We are dedicated to improve the quality of life for children, youth and families through prevention, intervention, and education through a coordinated range of services in Central, Northeast and South Los Angeles. El Centro provides services for families in a culturally, ethnically and linguistically competent basis. The Rampart/Pico Union Gang Reduction and Youth Development (GRYD) program of the City of Los Angeles is part of an intensive effort to foster youth development and reduce the influence of street gangs in the lives of our youth.  El Centro Del Pueblo (ECDP) is the lead agency for the Rampart/Pico Union area GRYD program and is currently working with families implementing prevention services. The Rampart/Pico Union-GRYD program works with “at risk” youth by providing:• Case Management• Family Genograms• Family Meetings• Home Visits• Home Assessments• Individual Counseling• Recreational ActivitiesAdditionally, a Multidisciplinary Case Planning Committee (MCPC) is comprised of the stakeholders involved with the client and families to discuss and create a case plan with the client. A case plan is then developed where both the parents and the client agree to participate and services are outlined targeting risk factors in the tool (YSET) assessment.  Referrals are made to El Centro Del Pueblo for mental health services on evidence based practices (EBP) therapy that is supported by scientific research.
Coverage: This program covers residents of the following counties: Los Angeles County, CA.

Service_name: Online Alcohol Treatment (Medication & Therapy) | Monument (Monument)
Eligibility: ['This program helps people who are older than 17 years old.']
Description: Monument is an online platform for anyone looking to change their relationship with alcohol. Monument connects you to physician consultations, medication options, specialized therapy, and community support to get you from where you are to where you want to be. This program provides:- Telehealth for alcohol use disorder- Medication options to support goals for sobriety or moderation -Virtual therapy designed to help you stop drinking or cut back Members have access to:- Virtual appointments with a licensed physician- Virtual  appointments with a licensed therapist - Chat-based messaging with your Care Team - Management of naltrexone or disulfiram prescription (optional)- An anonymous forum, available 24/7- Free virtual therapist-moderated support groups All Monument plans begin with a video appointment with a licensed physician. Your physician will prescribe medication if they deem it safe and appropriate for you. Medication is optional. Pending a prescription, you’ll be able to manage your prescription via our pharmacy partner that ships medication directly to your home.  You’ll be able to chat with your physician at any time, and schedule additional appointments as needed.  Depending on your plan, you can also connect with a specialized therapist on a weekly or biweekly basis. Therapy helps you develop healthier coping responses, build relapse prevention skills, create boundaries, address co-occuring conditions like anxiety and depression, change self-destructive habits, manage negative emotions, and so much more.
Coverage: This program covers residents of the following states: AZ, CA, CO, CT, DC, FL, GA, IA, KY, NJ, NY, OH, OR, PA, SC, TX, VA and WA.

Service_name: Mental Health and Wellness Restorative Weekend (Caregivers on the Homefront)
Eligibility: ['Serves family members and caregivers of all era wounded, ill veterans.']
Description: The Mental Health and Wellness Restorative Weekend is a weekend-long workshop for veterans, first responders and their families in which they will participate in interactive workshops that focus on a variety of topics that surround the caregiver - self-care, identity, physical health, emotions, suicide, and resiliency.  Services provided:-Mental Health Workshops-Wellness trainingWe want to provide you with tools so that when you return home you are better equipped to navigate this journey we are all on together. We also hope you find a solid foundation and a wonderful caregiver tribe to ensure your resiliency. Mental Health weekends will take place in Kansas City, MO and Caregivers on the Homefront will supply travel, hotel, activities and all meals. If selected for the Restorative Weekend, you will be asked to submit a $100 deposit to secure your spot, which will be refunded to you during the last evening of the event. If you fail to show up for the Restorative Weekend, your deposit will not be returned to you unless there is proof of a medical emergency. If this presents a problem to you financially, we have a very limited amount of scholarships available.Workshops are scheduled for three to four times a year; during COVID-19, the weekends will still take place and we will abide by our local guidelines for social distancing and mask wearing.Visit our website to apply.
Coverage: This program covers residents of the following states: AK, AL, AR, AZ, CA, CO, CT, DC, DE, FL, GA, HI, IA, ID, IL, IN, KS, KY, LA, MA, MD, ME, MI, MN, MO, MS, MT, NC, ND, NE, NH, NJ, NM, NV, NY, OH, OK, OR, PA, RI, SC, SD, TN, TX, UT, VA, VT, WA, WI, WV and WY.

Serving: ['anyone in need', 'adults', 'young adults', 'teens', 'seniors', 'deaf or hard of hearing', 'individuals', 'families', 'trauma survivors', 'in crisis', 'all mental health', 'substance dependency', 'dual diagnosis']
Eligibility: ['This program serves individuals and families facing mental and/or substance use disorders.']
Description: SAMHSA’s National Helpline, also known as the Treatment Referral Routing Service, is a confidential, free, 24-hour-a-day, 365-day-a-year, information service, in English and Spanish, for individuals and family members facing mental and/or substance use disorders.This program provides:- Referrals to local treatment facilities, support groups, and community based organizations- Free publications and informationThe service is confidential. SAMHSA will not ask for any personal information. Zip code or other pertinent geographic information may be required in order to track calls being routed to other offices or to accurately identify the local resources appropriate to the person's needs. If a person is seeking treatment and have no insurance or are underinsured, this program will refer them to the state office, which is responsible for state-funded treatment programs. Referrals to facilities that charge on a sliding fee scale or accept Medicare or Medicaid are also available. If a person has health insurance, they are encouraged to contact the insurer for a list of participating health care providers and facilities.The SAMHSA’s National Helpline does not provide counseling.
Coverage: This program covers residents of the following states: AK, AL, AR, AZ, CA, CO, CT, DC, DE, FL, GA, HI, IA, ID, IL, IN, KS, KY, LA, MA, MD, ME, MI, MN, MO, MS, MT, NC, ND, NE, NH, NJ, NM, NV, NY, OH, OK, OR, PA, RI, SC, SD, TN, TX, UT, VA, VT, WA, WI, WV and WY.

Vet Centers guide Veterans and their families through many of the major adjustments in lifestyle that often occur after a Veteran returns from combat. All services are prepaid through the Veteran's service. Contact your nearest Vet Center through information provided in the Vet Center Directory or listings in your local blue pages. Service_name: Our Programs (Counseling4Kids)
Other_Services: ['mental health care', 'family counseling', 'individual counseling', 'medications for mental health', 'mental health evaluation']
Serving: ['teens', 'children', 'trauma survivors', 'abuse or neglect survivors', 'domestic violence survivors']
Eligibility: ['This program helps people who are younger than 21 years old.', 'A child who has full-scope Medi-Cal eligibility for Los Angeles County.', 'Court authorization has been given for the child to receive mental health services', 'Bring a copy of the child’s MediCal Card or MediCal Authorization letter', 'Bring a copy of Court Minute Order stating child is to receive counseling.', 'Complet a Referral Form']
Description: The introduction of Cal-Aim has allowed us to broaden the scope for the clients whom we serve. The change is exceptionally helpful, as we have experienced a significant increase in the number of clients that are being referred to Counseling4Kids. Presently, our company has opportunity to provide services for clients who present with a mild-to-moderate range of symptoms. We have dedicated programs to cater to the needs of the clients which include: Stepped Care, Targeted Case Management Services, Psychological Testing Services, Prevention and Early Intervention (PEI). General Outpatient and Multi-disciplinary Assessment Team (MAT) Stepped Care: The Stepped Care Model for services allows for C4K to provide quick access to the care that our clients need. Stepped Care is a system of delivering and monitoring mental health treatment so that the most effective, yet least resource intensive treatment is delivered first, only "stepping up" to intensive / specialist services as required and depending on the level of client distress or need. Stepped care requires treatments of differing intensity. Thus, stepped interventions offer a variety of treatment options to match the intensity of the client's presenting problem as well as potential client preference. Targeted Case Management Services: We have a dedicated team of case managers who provide targeted case management services that help clients, and their families gain access to needed medical, social, educational and other services. Most recently our case managers have connected our families with Sandpiper Kohl's Back-to-School Shopping Event. The event supported our client's ability to return to school with greater confidence for the start of the new year. Our case managers also support our clients through skills building and medication management. Psychological and Psychiatric Testing Services: Psychologists and psychiatrists are available to support individuals who require specialized care. Our in-house psychiatric team and psychological services provide the assessments to ensure that clients receive a more intense level of service. Additionally, our psychiatric team prescribes medication as needed to our clients, which supports the efficacy of treatment. Our multidisciplinary method of treatment allows our case managers, clinicians, psychologist and psychiatrists to work together for the benefit and well-being of our clients. The following is required to process your referral: - Copy of the child’s MediCal Card or MediCal Authorization letter - Copy of Court Minute Order stating child is to receive counseling (if applicable) - Completed Referral Form (can be found linked to our website). If you want to refer a child in the Northern or Southern region of LA County use the link; https://www.counseling4kids.org/wp-content/uploads/2023/02/C4K-Referral-2022.pdf
Coverage: This program covers residents of the following counties: Los Angeles County, CA.

Description: Centro De Bienestar Familiar specializes in providing psychological and case management services to abused and traumatized victims, children with emotional and behavioral problems, family members in relational conflicts, and individuals with multiple psychological and psychiatric conditions. This program provides:- Individual, family, and group therapy- Completion of legal forms and certifications- Psychological testing for intellectual abilities and functioning, developmental delays/disorders, mental state, immigration cases, and others- Referrals for psychiatric and medical evaluations - Case management services- Domestic Violence Prevention & Treatment- Play and Art Therapy for Children- Psycho-Educational Training, Including Parenting Training- Evaluations and Psychological Reports for Immigration or Other Legal MattersThis program can help with the following:- ADHD- Anxiety- Depression- Domestic Violence- Childhood and Adolescents Mood and Behavioral Problems- Issues of Abuse and Trauma-Related Symptomatology - Relationships and Family Conflicts- Self-Esteem and Personal Growth- Stress Management- Substance Abuse and Impulsive BehaviorsIn most cases, the therapeutic services are free or a low co-payment through private insurance, the victims of crime program, or Medi-Medi (those covered by Medicare and Medi-Cal).

Service_name: Face It TOGETHER (Face It Together)
Main_Services: ['addiction & recovery', 'substance abuse counseling', 'peer recovery coaching', 'navigating the system', 'one-on-one support', 'peer support', 'virtual support']
Eligibility: ['This program helps people who are older than 17 years old']
Description: At Face It TOGETHER, we believe people impacted by addiction, including their loved ones, deserve the same dignity and respect as anyone else affected by a serious illness. Our expert coaches help you discover your path to wellness. If you're a loved one, or struggling with the disease, we're with you every step of the way. Our professional peer coaches help guide you through the challenges you're facing around addiction. Your coach is your wellness partner, providing knowledge, support and skills – or accountability – depending on your needs. We focus on improving every aspect of your life – not just the part that involves drinking or using.You'll receive high-quality, confidential and non-judgmental support from our expert coaches:- Assessments of current strengths, challenges and risks- Personalized addiction management plan and action steps- Weekly coaching sessions- Specialized support for people with the disease and loved ones- Data to track your progress- Convenient options including coaching by video, phone or in person- Unlimited messaging with coach- Connection to resources to support addiction wellness- Navigation to treatment and clinical care as neededFace It TOGETHER has a number of sponsored memberships available for those in financial need. To get started, call or text us at 855-539-9375.
Coverage: This program covers residents of All US states and territories.

Service_name: Online Support Meetings (Postpartum Support International (PSI))
Serving: ['adults', 'young adults', 'teens', 'active duty', 'grieving', 'lgbtqia+', 'transgender or non-binary', 'pregnant', 'individuals', 'families', 'single parent', 'limited english', 'african american', 'asian', 'latino', 'parents', 'depression', 'bipolar', 'anxiety', 'ptsd']
Eligibility: ['This program serves new parents seeking mental health and peer support.']
Description: Perinatal Support International offers online support groups for parents suffering from perinatal mood and anxiety disorders, the most common complication of childbirth. PSI Online Support Group Meetings are led by trained PSI facilitators, and the online groups will connect parents with other parents and provide helpful tools and resources. This program provides: - Online support groups. PSI provides a variety of free, virtual support groups focusing on perinatal mental health. These include specialized groups for different needs and demographics, such as ADHD, bipolar disorders, birth trauma, and specific support for Black, Indigenous, and People of Color (BIPOC). There are also groups addressing loss and grief related to early pregnancy, fertility challenges, and stillbirth. Additionally, PSI offers support for diverse family structures and situations, including groups for military families, NICU parents, single parents, and LGBTQIA+ parents. Please create an account to attend a support group.   Note: PSI peer support groups are free and do not require a Sharewell subscription to attend.
Coverage: This program covers residents of All US states and territories.

Service_name: WWP Talk (Wounded Warrior Project (WWP))
Eligibility: ['Must have suffered a physical or mental injury, wound, or illness during your military service on or after September 11, 2001, or be a registered family service member and/or caregiver to an individual that has.', 'WWP Talk is available to all warriors, family members, and caregivers registered with WWP. It’s most appropriate for those who are not experiencing a crisis and who are ready to discuss emotional issues and set goals leading to improved mental health.', 'WWP Talk provides nonclinical emotional support and isn’t meant to take the place of any clinical treatment, therapy, or counseling you may be receiving.']
Description: Since 2013, the WWP Talk team has provided a listening ear and a safe, nonjudgmental outlet for warriors and their family members. Our team is committed to you and will collaborate set goals aimed at processing and overcoming challenges. During your participation, you’ll build resilience, develop coping skills, reduce stress levels, and achieve goals that will improve your quality of life. Many who participate in the program also develop improved relationships with friends and loved ones. Our goal-setting model is not only beneficial while participating in the program but can be applied to daily life situations well after you have completed the program. WWP Talk is a free nonclinical, telephonic, emotional support and goal-setting program. The program helps both warriors and family members plan individualized paths toward personal growth. Participants work one-on-one with a dedicated team member during weekly emotional support calls. Together, they set tangible SMART goals and develop skills that lead to positive changes, like increased resilience, improved psychological well-being, and improved overall quality of life. To join the program, you must first register with us. For more information or to sign up for the program, call our Resource Center at 888.WWP.ALUM (997.2586) or 904.405.1213.
Coverage: This program covers residents of All US states and territories.

Description: Sound Off delivers vital, long-term mental health support for veterans, actively serving military (active duty, reserve, national guard), and intelligence officers while maintaining anonymity of the person seeking help. This program provides: - Mental health counseling - Peer support. Calls are conducted via secure voip technology and messages are end-to-end encrypted meaning — no phone number required. You can read clinician’s backgrounds, see their certifications, their veteran status, and choose the right fit for yourself.
Coverage: This program covers residents of the following states: AK, AL, AR, AZ, CA, CO, CT, DC, DE, FL, GA, HI, IA, ID, IL, IN, KS, KY, LA, MA, MD, ME, MI, MN, MO, MS, MT, NC, ND, NE, NH, NJ, NM, NV, NY, OH, OK, OR, PA, RI, SC, SD, TN, TX, UT, VA, VT, WA, WI, WV and WY.

Description: SHIELDS’ Revelation Dual Diagnosis Program was designed to help youth and adolescents maintain a positive and productive drug-free lifestyle that promotes meaningful and beneficial relationships and connections to family, peers, and the community both during treatment and after treatment ends.Our comprehensive and collaborative services include:- Case management- Individual, group, and family counseling-Educational and vocational services- Life skills classes- Drug and alcohol education- Child development and parenting- Urinalysis testingIn addition, participants may receive linkage and referral services to additional substance use and mental health treatment  programs at SHIELDS and other community-based providers, as well as linkage to our collaborative networks that provide housing, food, clothing, and transportation for those in need. This program operates during weekday afternoons for three hours. Program staff perform complete intakes and psychosocial assessments for each client utilizing the Teen Addiction Severity Index (TASI). Assessments include medical histories, drug use histories, legal, vocational, educational, mental health information, and physical exams. SHIELDS’ Youth Substance Abuse Treatment programs are primarily funded by the Los Angeles County Department of Mental Health (DMH) and the Los Angeles County Probation Department (Probation).

Serving: ['adults', 'young adults', 'teens', 'seniors', 'in jail', 'pregnant', 'chronic illness', 'homeless', 'limited english', 'all mental health', 'substance dependency', 'criminal justice history']
Eligibility: ['Must have an involvement with the justice system (pre-booking, probation, or incarceration) within the last 3 months; AND', '1 Emergency Department visit in the past 6 months; or 1 hospital visit in the past 12 months; AND', 'At least one of the following: Chronic medical condition; Serious mental illness;Substance Use Disorder; Homelessness; or Pregnant.']
Description: The Whole Person Care Reentry program aims to enroll 1,000 LA County jail inmates per month who are eligible for Medi-Cal, are high utilizers of health or behavioral health services, and are at high risk due to chronic medical conditions, mental illness, substance use disorders, homelessness, or pregnancy. An additional 400 individuals per month recently released from custody will be enrolled from the community, via referrals from Probation, California Department of Corrections and Rehabilitation, and community-based reentry services agencies.Services provided (within the jail setting):- In-person meetings with identified inmates within the first 3 days in custody, to conduct a comprehensive psychosocial assessment and develop a re-entry care plan- Increased Medi-Cal enrollment efforts- Referrals to Homeless Initiative programs- Provision of a 30-day supply of prescription medication at release for participants with chronic health or mental health conditions- Generation of a Continuity of Care Document for transmittal to the participant’s health care provider in the community- Establishment of a Whole Person Care release desk to arrange transportation, shelter or other services- An in-person or video-conference visit with the Community Health Worker (CHW) to be assigned to the participant in the community, where feasible, to facilitate a warm handoff upon releaseServices provided post-release:- Mentorship and social support- Health and social service navigation- Linkage to housing, employment, education, legal assistance and social supports- Accompaniment to key health and behavioral health appointments- Assistance with adherence to appointments, treatments and medications- Connection to transportationThe average length of service for the Re-entry program is 3 months, with a subset of participants receiving 9 months of services.
Coverage: This program covers residents of the following counties: Los Angeles County, CA.

Service_name: Freedom Re-Entry Center (Freedom Re-Entry Center)
Eligibility: ['For initial entry into Freedom Re-Entry Sober Home (FRESH)  ; You must be sober. You must have the ability to pass an alcohol and drug test. You must agree to take random urine exams and alcohol breath tests weekly. Urine Exams and testing kits are provided by house management.']
Description: Freedom Re-Entry Center was established by two men who experienced first hand the pain and anguish of addiction and established Freedom Re-Entry Sober Home (FRESH) in 2008. Through the transforming love of Jesus Christ and a solid twelve-step program, they found they were able to re-establish their relationship with God, their families and their communities. They have the sincere desire to share with others what they have found, by providing a safe, clean, sober Christ based living environment.Paul and Mario’s hope is to provide a new start for men struggling with substance addiction and abuse issues. Their primary goal is to help men stay clean and sober and regain their lives, families, connection with God and their re-entry to their community. We take men sincerely willing to change their lives including those with felony convictions, on parole or probation, suffering from mental illness and other addiction related life difficulties.FRESH is located in a quiet suburban neighborhood conveniently located just south of the 10 freeway at 9867 Brockway Ave El Monte, CA 91733.FRESH has 6 beds available for those who have a sincere desire to stop drinking and stop using drugs in a supportive Christian environment.To be considered for residency please contact Paul De Leon at 562-965-0740 or David Church at 562-556-3838.
Coverage: This program covers residents of the following counties: Los Angeles County, CA.

Description: End-of-Life Care Program provides assistance and support services to your loved one who is nearing the end of their life or struggling with a chronic illness. Our trained caregivers make this trying time as comfortable as possible for your loved one and your whole family. We provide personal care assistance, companionship, medication reminders, light housekeeping and food preparation. Toward the end of a loved one’s life, you may be feeling stressed out, depressed, angry or overwhelmed. Our caregivers provide emotional and moral support for the whole family. We also continue to provide support and assistance after your loved one has passed. We serve Pasadena and the surrounding areas which include Altadena, Arcadia, Glendale, La Canada Flintridge, Monterey Park, San Gabriel, San Marino, South Pasadena, Temple City and West Covina.
Coverage: This program covers residents of the following counties: Los Angeles County, CA.

Eligibility: ['Must have Medicare or Medicaid.']
Description: Alzheimer’s Care Program provides relief services to you and to help your loved one retain their comfort and dignity as long as possible. Our caregivers are trained and certified to provide empathetic, patient and compassionate care to those with Alzheimer’s. We help and make your loved one feel safe and calm through emotional support and assistance around the house. We focus on working on their remaining strengths and abilities, allowing us to put the emphasis on their care and dignity—not on the disease itself. We offer specialized Alzheimer’s care services to help take some of the responsibility and stress off of your shoulders. We serve Pasadena and the surrounding areas which include; Altadena, Arcadia, Glendale, La Canada Flintridge, Monterey Park, San Gabriel, San Marino, South Pasadena, Temple City and West Covina.
Coverage: This program covers residents of the following counties: Los Angeles County, CA.

Service_name: Basics (NAMI San Fernando Valley)
Eligibility: ['This program serves parents and family caregivers of children and teens who are experiencing symptoms of a mental illness or whom have already been diagnosed.']
Description: NAMI Basics is a free, 6-week education program for parents and family caregivers of children and teens who are experiencing symptoms of a mental illness or whom have already been diagnosed. NAMI Basics is offered on-line and can be accessed anywhere anytime. It is also offered in person by other NAMI affiliates in Los Angeles like NAMI Glendale. NAMI Basics covers:- Managing crises, solving problems and communicating effectively- How to take care of yourself and handle stress- Developing the confidence and stamina to support your child with compassion- Advocating for your child's rights at school and in health care settings- Learning about current treatments, including evidence-based therapies, medications and side effects- Gaining an overview of the public mental health care, school and juvenile justice systems- Understanding the challenges and impact of mental health conditions on your entire family
Coverage: This program covers residents of the following counties: Los Angeles County, CA.

Service_name: Family to Family (NAMI San Fernando Valley)
Description: NAMI Family-to-Family is a free, 8-session educational program for family, significant others and friends of people living with mental illness.  NAMI Family-to-Family is taught by NAMI-trained family members who have been there, and includes presentations, discussion and interactive exercises. In the program, you'll learn about: - How to manage crises, solve problems and communicate effectively - Taking care of yourself and managing your stress - Developing the confidence and stamina to provide support with compassion - Finding and using local supports and services - Up-to-date information on mental health conditions and how they affect the brain - Current treatments, including evidence-based therapies, medications and side effects - The impact of mental illness on the entire family. Pre-registration is required for all NAMI SFV classes.  Due to high demand, you may be placed on a wait-list. All seats are filled in the order requests are received.
Coverage: This program covers residents of the following counties: Los Angeles County, CA.

Service_name: HOPE Behavioral Health, Neuropsychology and Education Service (Children's Hospital Los Angeles (CHLA))
Main_Services: ['health education', 'mental health evaluation', 'mental health care', 'counseling', 'family counseling', 'navigating the system', 'support network', 'one-on-one support']
Serving: ['teens', 'children', 'cancer', 'families', 'childhood cancer survivors', 'facing end of life', 'on-treatment', 'post-treatment', 'young adult cancer survivors', 'recently diagnosed']
Location_Address: 1300 N Vermont Ave, Los Angeles, CA 90027
Eligibility: ['The HOPE Behavioral Health, Neuropsychology and Education Service at CHLA provides psychosocial support and education to patients diagnosed and treated in our Cancer and Blood Disease Institute.']
Description: The HOPE Behavioral Health, Neuropsychology and Education Service at CHLA provides psychosocial support and education to patients diagnosed and treated in our Children's Center for Cancer and Blood Diseases.Our services are timely, effective, and carefully integrated with medical care. Our clinicians work along with physicians, nurses, and other members of the healthcare team to ensure that our patients receive not only the best medical care, but also the best psychosocial support so that they continue to develop and thrive in all aspects of life as they receive medical treatment. Our Behavioral Health Service provides:-  psychological consultation- evaluation- treatment for families using techniques and interventions that are supported by research. We adapt these interventions to meet the unique demands of the medical setting, providing them to families in the inpatient hospital as well as outpatient clinics, ensuring continued support for families throughout their child’s illness. We offer a special program designed to meet the particularly challenging needs of adolescents and their families, called Teen and Family Support.Our Neuropsychology Service evaluates the neurobiological and cognitive consequences of childhood cancer and blood diseases, providing specific recommendations to children and families that ensure optimal social, emotional, and educational development that continues long after medical treatments have concluded.The HOPE Health Education Service provides educational classes, materials, and resources to help patients and families with the information and support resources they need to navigate through their experience with cancer or blood diseases.The HOPE Resource Center (HRC) is a central location that provides educational information on cancer or blood diseases. This includes:-  free educational materials on disease and treatment - computer and internet access- information on camps and scholarships- support groups and wellness workshops- book library- on-site community agency presentations- educational sessions for patients and families led by a pediatric hematology/oncology Health Educator.The School Transition and Re-entry (STAR) Service seeks to empower young people with cancer and blood diseases to succeed in school. We provide information, materials and consultation services to assist patients with navigating the school system and advocating for their school-based needs.  We also serve as a communication link between patients, the medical team, school, and community resources. Our staff is well informed about the unique medical, educational and social needs of young people with cancer and blood diseases.
Coverage: This program covers residents of the following counties: Los Angeles County, CA.

Service_name: Prevention and Early Intervention (PEI) (Alma Family Services)
Main_Services: ['understand mental health', 'group therapy', 'family counseling', 'individual counseling', 'support network']
Location_Address: 1000 Corporate Center Dr, Monterey Park, CA 91754
Description: Prevention and Early Intervention (PEI) focus on evidence-based services, education, support and outreach to help inform and identify those who may be affected by some level of mental health issue. Mental Health services offered under the PEI plan are deeply rooted in the various Evidence Based Practice treatment models, and are provided with a strong emphasis on fidelity to the model, which requires participation in many weeks/months of consultation calls with the developers or their identified representatives. The focus of early intervention services is to avoid the need for more extensive mental health treatment, or prevent the mental health problem from becoming worse. Various Evidence Based Services focus on specific age groups covering the life span from young children to older adults. Under Alma Family Services’ Prevention and Early Intervention (PEI) programs, efforts are made to increase prevention efforts and response to early signs of emotional and behavioral health problems among at-risk individuals. Providing mental health education, outreach and early identification (prior to diagnosis) can mitigate costly negative long-term outcomes for mental health clients and their families.Evidence Based Practices Offered at Alma Family Services:- Parent Child Interactive Therapy (PCIT)- Cognitive Behavioral Intervention for Trauma in Schools (CBITS)- Trauma Focused Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (TF-CBT)- Managing and Adapting Practice (MAP)- Seeking Safety- Problem Solving Therapy (PST)- Mental Health Integration Program (MHIP)- Crisis Oriented Recovery Services (CORS)- Program to Encourage Active, Rewarding Lives for Seniors (PEARLS)- Interpersonal Psychotherapy (IPT)
Coverage: This program covers residents of the following counties: Los Angeles County, CA.

Service_name: Funeral Consumers Alliance (Funeral Consumers Alliance)
Description: Many FCA affiliates, with the help of their volunteers, do a price survey of area mortuaries. Some have been able to negotiate a discount at participating funeral homes, sort of like a cooperative buyers’ club. Some focus on education and advocacy only. Joining and supporting a local FCA group will help you save thousands of dollars on unnecessary funeral costs while ensuring we can protect a consumer’s last rights in your neighborhood and around the country.We offer:- Funeral assistanceOur affiliates are nonsectarian, nonprofit, educational organizations. They were first started in the late 1930s (known then as Memorial Societies) because of two influences: the depression and the increasing cost of funerals due to the use of embalming and more elaborate manufactured caskets. Visit our website for more information or contact the office closest to you.
Coverage: This program covers residents of the following states: CA.

Service_name: Medication-Assisted Treatment for Opioids (MAT) (Groups Recover Together)
Main_Services: ['addiction & recovery', 'substance abuse counseling', 'medications for addiction', 'peer support', 'support groups', 'virtual support']
Eligibility: ['This program serves individuals who have an opioid addiction.']
Description: Groups Recover Together provide effective and affordable treatment to recover from opiate use. The opiate recovery treatment community provides medication (Suboxone) and weekly therapy sessions with other people recovering from opiates. While such medicines should typically be used for 18-24 months, the community at Groups Recover Together is for life.This program provides:- Medication-assisted treatment- Group therapy Groups Recover Together accepts Medicaid and offers a discounted private pay fee for those who are uninsured. For an affordable weekly fee you can get the therapy and medication you need to regain control over your life. The intake assessment is the same price. You will never be asked to pay for drug screens, extra appointments or other additional services. Groups Recover Together price does not include the cost of medication. If you have any form of insurance, Groups Recover Together will file a prior authorization so the cost of your medication will be covered. If you do not have insurance, medication typically costs $45-50 per week.***Due to COVID-19, Groups Recover Together has transitioned to a fully virtual, telehealth model to ensure limited disruption to your medication and clinical experience. Weekly meetings will be conducted via videoconferencing, and will be at the same time as your current group. Once you attend your first telehealth group, your counselor will share info on how to continue to comply with the urine drug screen, pill count, and medication policies.
Coverage: This program covers residents of the following states: CA, CO, FL, IN, KY, ME, NC, NH, NV, RI, SC, TN, VA and WV.

Service_name: Addiction: Intensive Adult Outpatient Program (Tarzana Treatment Centers, Inc. (TTC))
Main_Services: ['addiction & recovery', 'outpatient treatment', 'substance abuse counseling', 'medications for addiction']
Other_Services: ['sober living', 'substance abuse counseling', 'peer recovery coaching', 'daily life skills', 'nutrition education', 'parenting education']
Eligibility: ['Meet Medi-Cal eligibility.', 'This program serves people with substance dependency.']
Description: The Intensive Outpatient Program is a year long program made up of three, 8 week treatment phases, followed by six months of aftercare. During the intensive alcohol and drug treatment component, participants are involved in a variety of group modalities in addition to weekly individual counseling sessions. Both day and evening tracks are available to better accommodate patient’s work or other schedules.This program provides:- Intensive outpatient program for addictionThe program consists of three phases. Below is the break down of each phase:- Phase 1: Participants attend a minimum of two, ninety minute groups per day, either three or five days per week.- Phase 2: Participants attend a minimum of two, ninety minute groups per day, two times per week.- Phase 3: Participants attend a minimum of 2, ninety minute groups per day, one time per week. In addition, they offer Aftercare which consists of weekly group meetings and semi-monthly alumni meetings for people who completed the 12-week alcohol and drug treatment program and addresses day-to-day and long-term recovery issues. They also offer Family Education, Youth Services, and Mental Health Counseling. Drug Medi-Cal outpatient services are available now to all Medi-Cal eligible patients including youth and adults.
Coverage: This program covers residents of the following counties: Los Angeles County, CA and Orange County, CA.

Description: OPICAs  Counseling Center offers support groups and individual, couples and family counseling.  OPICAs support groups and supportive services are open to the public and offered five days a week.  Support Groups:Our support groups impart information and comfort, and facilitate discussion in a warm and open atmosphere as individuals endeavor to find their own balance. Sessions focus on strategies for emotional support, stress reduction, lifestyle changes, relationships, depression and crisis management. The groups meet once a week and are limited to eight people. Support groups are offered at three locations: OPICA-Spousal Support GroupsTuesday 10am-11:30am and Thursday 10am-11:15amAdult Children Support Group-Monday or Wednesday 5:30pm-7:00pmCombined Adult Children & Spousal Support Group Friday 8:30am-10:00amBelmont Village Senior Living, WestwoodCombined Spousal & Adult Children Support Group Friday 10:15am-12noonSilverado, Beverly Place-Combined Spousal & Adult Children Support GroupWednesday 10:30am-12noonEnrollment requires initial phone consultation with group facilitator.Individual, Couples and Family Counseling is available for those in need of more focused help. Our licensed Marriage and Family Therapists and supervised interns are available to support those learning to cope with emotional and/or relational challenges such as depression, grief and life transitions in addition to the changes associated with early memory loss and related chronic illnesses.  We support clients towards expanding options, and creating and achieving meaningful goals.  Contact Anne Galbraith, Emily Carvill or Georgi Marshall for more information on enrollment and locations for any of our counseling programs call 310-478-0226.
Coverage: This program covers residents of the following counties: Los Angeles County, CA.

Description: KYCC (Koreatown Youth and Community Center) serves the evolving needs of the Korean American population in the greater Los Angeles area as well as the multiethnic Koreatown community. KYCC’s programs and services are directed toward recently immigrated, economically disadvantaged youth and families, and promote community socioeconomic empowerment.At KYCC our goal is to provide a broad continuum of high quality and culturally relevant clinical services for low-income children, youth and their families. Many of our clients are unserved or underserved from a lack of culturally or linguistically relevant services. We offer short-term programs, help clients transition into recovery, and serve participants who may be beyond the scope of traditional outpatient services. We also provide medication management, individual and family-based case management, child abuse prevention and intervention, and parenting education.Prevention & Early Intervention Services provide individuals ages 0-15, short-term early mental health services that utilize evidence-based treatment models to minimize chronic mental health system involvement.  In order to receive service you must speak with an Intake Counselor (English, Korean, or Spanish available). The Intake Counselor will then screen you for eligibility. You will then be added to the waitlist or referred to another organization.
Coverage: This program covers residents of the following counties: Los Angeles County, CA.

Description: The Asian Smokers’ Quitline (ASQ) is a free nationwide Asian-language quit smoking service operated by the Moores Cancer Center at the University of California, San Diego. Service_name: Family Links/North Valley Youth & Family Center (San Fernando Valley Community Mental Health Center, Inc.)
Main_Services: ['psychiatric emergency services', 'specialized therapy', 'mental health care', 'group therapy', 'navigating the system', 'one-on-one support']
Eligibility: ['This program helps people who are 0 to 21 years old.', 'Families with at least one parent with severe and persistent mental illness at least one child with serious emotional disturbance. The program may also serve a child or adolescent with serious emotional disturbance who does not have a parent qualified for services.']
Description: The San Fernando Valley Community Mental Health Center, Inc. founded in 1970, is a private, non-profit agency dedicated to improving the mental health of individuals and families within the community. Primary emphasis is placed on providing services to children, adolescents and transitional age youth with serious emotional disorders, and services for adults and older adults with severe and persistent mental illness. The Center is committed to treating all consumers with dignity and enhancing their quality of life.Family Links/North Valley Youth & Family Center:Children, ages 0-18 (or older if still in high school), can be seen in one of three outpatient centers located in Mission Hills, Central Van Nuys, and East Van Nuys. Overall, services are geared toward increasing the adaptive functioning of children in their homes, schools, and communities by providing supportive and individualized intervention, which may include:-Mental Health Services – assessment, individual/family/group therapy, collateral work with caregivers, and rehabilitation to increase specific skill sets. Clinicians at the three centers are trained in a variety of evidenced-based practices as well as traditional therapeutic approaches.-Medication Support Services – psychiatric evaluation and ongoing medication management as needed.-Targeted Case Management – linkage to and collaboration with other public and private agencies, providers, and services.Crisis Intervention – immediate intervention to stabilize or ensure linkage to a higher level of care.Additional services are available at our Mission Hills site, where the treatment team has developed a specialization in Infant Mental Health, focusing upon early developmental screening, assessment, and intervention in order to promote healthy parent-child relationships, the achievement of early developmental milestones, and resiliency for our clients between the ages of birth and five years. This program may also treat families including at least one parent with severe and persistent mental illness and at least one child who is concurrently experiencing emotional disturbance and impairments in his or her adaptive functioning at home, at school, or in the community.Target Population: Families with at least one parent with severe and persistent mental illness at least one child with serious emotional disturbance. The program may also serve a child or adolescent with serious emotional disturbance who does not have a parent qualified for services.Ages of Population: Children and adolescents between the ages of 0-21.For more information call (818) 361-5030.For outpatient services, please call 818-574-7745.
Coverage: This program covers residents of the following counties: Los Angeles County, CA.

Description: The MAT program is a Countywide collaboration between the Department of Mental Health (DMH), the Department of Children and Family Services (DCFS), and contracted Community Mental Health providers. This program is designed to ensure the immediate, thorough, and comprehensive assessment of children and youth who have been detained through DCFS and are entering out-of-home placements. The assessment includes findings addressing the child’s needs (medical, dental, developmental, speech/language, educational, vocational, mental health and family/caregiver) The information gathered in these assessments is used by the courts to determine needs, appropriate services and appropriate placement. Service_name: The G.U.Y.S. Program (Friends Research Institute, Inc. - Friends Community Center)
Location_Address: 1419 N La Brea Ave, Los Angeles, CA 90028
Description: The G.U.Y.S. Program is a health education/risk reduction intervention designed to reduce high-risk sexual and drug behaviors among substance-using gay men and non-gay identified men who have sex with men, with women, and with transgender women.  The program provides a continuum of culturally appropriate services from street-based outreach encounters to site-based groups and one-on-one interventions that work concomitantly to motivate ongoing and sustained HIV risk reductions. Most specifically the intervention targets sexual risk behaviors that are most likely to occur while using methamphetamine, particularly unprotected anal intercourse as well as exchange sex risks and injection drug risks.The program offers a daily meal as well as a daily group. Program participants contribute art, poetry and prose to our street-based ‘zine, Twacked: A ‘Zine from the Guys of the Boulevard created and published by Friends Community Center. Our experience using art with active users has demonstrated that hands-on art exploration provides an opportunity for participants to closely identify their feelings and work toward better understanding their high-risk behaviors.
Coverage: This program covers residents of the following counties: Los Angeles County, CA.

Service_name: Pasadena Council on Alcoholism and Drug Dependence (PCADD) (Social Model Recovery Systems)
Description: Social Model Recovery Systems (a non-profit 501(c)3 California corporation) provides direct treatment services (at 12 locations in Los Angeles and Orange Counties) for those whose lives have become unmanageable due to alcohol and other drug use and/or whose mental health issues are interfering with leading productive lives. We know that ultimately recovery is a personal choice, but we here at Social Model Recovery Systems are here to assist you in your steps to a healthier lifestyle. Social Model Recovery Systems envisions a world where communities can pursue social, economic, educational, and spiritual wellness free from alcohol, other drug, and mental health problems.In the Pasadena Council on Alcoholism and Drug Dependence (PCADD) the treatment program is designed to meet the needs of people suffering from alcoholism and drug dependence. Included are assessment and evaluation, treatment planning and access to other resources, supervised implementation of the plan, monitored 12-step meeting attendance, education on addiction topics and issues, facilitated recovery support groups, and weekly individual counseling and case management. The Aftercare program provides on-going recovery and treatment support for up to a year after completion of the program. Available to adolescents as well as adults, families are also considered and included in the recovery process offered by this program.The program is partially funded by the County of Los Angeles, Substance Abuse Prevention and Control, and certified by the State of California. We accept participants receiving CalWORKS, Medi-Cal benefits, have insurance, or have the ability to pay a private rate.To get more information about the program call (877) 507-6242 or email [email protected].
Coverage: This program covers residents of the following counties: Los Angeles County, CA.

Service_name: Pap Smear (Claris Health)
Location_Address: 3737 Martin Luther King Junior Boulevard, Lynwood, CA 90262
Eligibility: ['This program helps people who are 12 to 65 years old.', 'This program helps individuals over the age of 12 who present certain risk factors determined by the medical professional.']
Description: Claris Health offers Pap Smears to help detect certain viral infections such as human papillomavirus (HPV), which is known to cause cervical cancer.  This program provides: - Pap smear. Cost: $50-$75 for Pap (w/ STI Testing). Financial aid available to qualifying patients. The pelvic exam also includes an inspection of external and internal genital areas and an assessment of the health of the reproductive system and organs. It can also help identify pelvic inflammatory disease (PID), fibroids, etc. Pap testing is available for all premenopausal women. Doctors recommend getting a Pap smear at 21 years of age and then at least once every three years. If you have certain risk factors, you may need to get them more frequently. These factors include: - Prior diagnosis of cervical cancer or a Pap smear that showed precancerous cells - Exposure to diethylstilbestrol (DES) before birth - HIV infection - Weakened immune system due to organ transplant, chemotherapy or chronic corticosteroid use - History of smoking
Coverage: This program covers residents of the following cities: Los Angeles, CA.

Description: The UCLA School of Nursing Health Clinic is devoted to caring for the primary medical needs of people experiencing homelessness. Please call for more information or to schedule an appointment.
Coverage: This program covers residents of the following counties: Los Angeles County, CA, Orange County, CA, Riverside County, CA, San Bernardino County, CA and Ventura County, CA.

This minimum duty requirement may not apply to Veterans who were discharged for a disability incurred or aggravated in the line of duty, discharged for a hardship, or received an 'early out.' Since there are a number of other exceptions to the minimum duty requirements, VA enc"]
Description: VHA Medical Centers provide a wide range of services including traditional hospital-based services as well as medical and surgical specialty services for Veterans enrolled in the VA health care program.This program provides: - Surgery- Critical care- Mental health- Orthopedics- Pharmacy- Radiology- Physical therapySpecialty services may include: - Audiology- Speech pathology- Dermatology- Dental care- Geriatrics- Hospice care- Neurology- Oncology- Podiatry- Prosthetics- Urology- Vision careSome medical centers also offer advanced services such as organ transplants and plastic surgery.Patient advocates, available at every medical center, are highly trained professionals who can help resolve your concerns about any aspect of your health care experience, particularly those concerns that cannot be resolved at the point of care. Patient Advocates listen to any questions, problems, or special needs you have and refer your concerns to the appropriate Medical Center staff for resolution.To receive services, fill out an Application for Health Benefits (VA Form 10-10EZ), go to your nearest VA medical center or clinic and bring a your signed Application for Health Benefits (VA Form 10-10EZ) with you. You may also apply for benefits online or by mail. Call our toll-free hotline at 877-222-8387, Monday through Friday, 8:00 a.m. to 8:00 p.m. ET to get help with your application.
Coverage: This program covers residents of All US states and territories.

Service_name: Support Groups for Adults (New Hope Grief Support Community)
Description: New Hope provides grief support groups for those who have lost a spouse, significant other, life partner, sibling, friend, parent, or child. Each grief group consists of eight to twelve members, and provides an environment for sharing, learning, and healing.  Services offered: - Grief support groupsEach support group runs for 8 weeks, and meets once a week in the evening for 1.5 hours.  There is a one-time $100 fee to attend the group which is used to help cover your materials, the facility, and the registration process. We are able to offer scholarships so that anyone in need can attend a group. We ask everyone to start the group enrollment process by filling out the interest form on our website. Your information will be kept confidential. Once you submit the interest form someone from our Support Team will contact you by phone for an intake interview. COVID-19 UPDATE:The health & safety of our group members and staff are our highest priority. For this reason, we are currently providing all services online via Zoom videoconferencing.
Coverage: This program covers residents of the following counties: Los Angeles County, CA.

Service_name: NAMI Peer-to-Peer (NAMI San Fernando Valley)
Description: NAMI Peer-to-Peer is a free, 10-session educational program for adults with mental illness who are looking to better understand their condition and journey toward recovery. NAMI Peer-to-Peer helps you: - Create a personalized relapse prevention plan - Learn how to interact with health care providers - Develop confidence for making decisions and reducing stress - Stay up-to-date on mental health research - Understand the impact of symptoms on your life - Access practical resources on how to maintain your journey toward recovery. Pre-registration is required for all NAMI SFV classes.
Coverage: This program covers residents of the following counties: Los Angeles County, CA.

Description: Wounded Warrior Project's Project Odyssey aims to empower veterans living with PTSD and other invisible wounds to push beyond their known limits and develop skills to discover their best selves.This program provides:- Mental health workshops- Support groupsThe program starts with a five-day mental health workshop, where warriors are challenged to step outside the comfort of their everyday routines. Service_name: NICU Parent Support-Virtual Support Groups (Hand To Hold)
Eligibility: ['This program serves individuals and families, who meet ONE of the following criteria: - are affected by a stay in the Neonatal Intensive Care Unit (NICU); - OR have a high-risk pregnancy; - OR experience preterm birth;- OR have babies with special healthcare needs;- OR have experienced the loss of a preterm infant or a pregnancy.']
Description: Hand to Hold® is a national nonprofit 501(c)(3) that is dedicated to providing personalized emotional support, education and community for NICU & bereaved parents. Early intervention mental health support is provided to parents at no cost to families and all support is designed with the emotional, physical and social needs of the NICU parent.  Our caring professional staff team (not volunteers) is comprised of trained NICU graduate and bereaved parents. Support groups are provided at no cost to NICU parents before, during and after their NICU stay. Groups are available in both English and Spanish. We currently host groups for: NICU Moms currently in the NICU, NICU Moms graduated from the NICU, NICU Parents (current and graduate), Black NICU Parents, High-Risk Pregnancy, Military NICU Families, Bereaved Parents. Groups are hosted by Hand to Hold’s Family Support Specialists,* staff members who have lived experience as a NICU parent. *Certified Mental Health Peer Specialist
Coverage: This program covers residents of All US states and territories.

Service_name: Youth Drug Abuse Prevention Program (YDAPP) (Koreatown Youth And Community Center (KYCC))
Description: The mission of KYCC is to serve the evolving needs of the Korean American population in the greater Los Angeles area as well as the multiethnic Koreatown community. KYCC’s programs and services are directed toward recently immigrated, economically disadvantaged youth and families and promote community socioeconomic empowerment.Through Youth Drug Abuse Prevention Program (YDAPP), KYCC offers a 10-month leadership program that trains youth advocates to raise substance abuse awareness among their peers in Koreatown and neighboring communities. Youth advocates participate in alcohol and drug-free events such as community clean-ups, health fairs and educational outreach, throughout the year. For more information, please contact Bryan Zaragoza Hurtado at [email protected] or (213) 365-7400 Ext.5119.
Coverage: This program covers residents of the following cities: Los Angeles, CA.

Location_Address: 1968 West Adams Boulevard, Los Angeles, CA 90018
Eligibility: ['This program helps people who are older than 17 years old.', 'Must be an African American mother that is 30 weeks or less into her pregnancy.']
Description: The California Black Infant Health (BIH) Program aims to improve health among African American mothers and babies and to reduce the Black: White disparities by empowering pregnant and mothering African American women to make healthy choices for themselves.This program provides:- Health Education and Counseling- Parenting Information- Nutrition Information- Social Support and Empowerment Classes- Parent Education and Father Support Classes- Community Resource Referrals- Bus Passes/Tokens- Prenatal/Postnatal Incentives- Home VisitsThe BIH uses a group-based approach with complementary client-centered case management to help women develop life skills, learn strategies for reducing stress, and build social support. BIH clients participate in weekly group sessions (10 prenatal and 10 postpartum) designed to help them access their own strengths and set health-promoting goals for themselves and their babies. In addition to helping clients reinforce the skills and knowledge they develop in the group sessions, one-on-one case management ensures that clients are connected with the appropriate community and social services to meet their needs. Each woman culminates her participation in the program by developing her own individual Life Plan to guide her continued progress after BIH.
Coverage: This program covers residents of the following counties: Los Angeles County, CA.

Description: The inTransition program is a free, confidential program that offers specialized coaching and assistance for active duty service members, National Guard members, reservists, veterans and retirees who need access to mental health care.This program provides:- An intake process to confirm service members' interest in participating, demographics, and current and gaining provider information, if available- Telephonic coaching sessions using motivational interviewing techniques that empower service members to determine their own paths to continue in care and improve their well-being- Answers to service members' questions about mental health care, treatment methods and techniques, provider types, outcomes measurement, etc.- Information on the use of military support services, community resources and support groupsTheir service is offered to service members who are: - Relocating to another assignment- Returning from deployment- Transitioning from active duty to reserve component or reserve component to active duty- Preparing to leave military service- Simply in need of a new mental health providerinTransition services are available to all military members regardless of length of service or discharge status and there is no expiration date to enroll. Clients may call and register any day or time, from any location, or you may ask for a referral from your health care provider or case manager.The inTransition program is accessible 24 hours a day, 7 days a week, 365 days a year via a toll-free phone number, email, or online chat.
Coverage: This program covers residents of All US states and territories.

Service_name: Remembrance Photography (Now I Lay Me Down to Sleep (NILMDTS))
Eligibility: ['Our guideline for dispatching a volunteer photographer for a Now I Lay Me Down to Sleep session is that the baby be at least 22 weeks gestation. This is a baseline from which medical professionals may deviate based upon their experience. It is possible that babies younger or older than 22 weeks would be either advisable or inadvisable.']
Description: Remembrance photography is an important step in the healing journey. Families are provided an intimate portrait session with the tangible gift of high-quality images as a part of their healing recovery and a forever keepsake. You will be treated with compassion and know that your babies are treasured by thoughtful interaction from NILMDTS.Services provided include:- Professional quality remembrance portraits for the families experiencing the death of a babyPhotographs are one of the most precious and tangible mementos parents can have, showing the love and bond that was given and shared with their baby. These portraits will last for generations, and will honor a tiny life that is forever loved and cherished.At your request, we will have an NILMDTS affiliated photographer come to your hospital or hospice location for a private and sensitive photography session. Our affiliated photographers are dedicated to making this photography session as loving, sensitive and private as possible.Visit our website and contact the Area Coordinator nearest to you to arrange an appointment with one of our volunteer photographers.
Coverage: This program covers residents of All 50 states.

Service_name: Hearing Dogs Program (Dogs For Better Lives)
Eligibility: ['A client must be willing and able to physically, mentally, and emotionally care for the dog without assistance.', 'Must not have another dog at home.', 'We typically require a fenced area attached to the home.', 'This program helps people who are older than 17 years old.', 'Must attend obedience training classes or hire a private obedience trainer as prescribed by your Dogs for Better Lives professional trainer.', 'Must be deaf or hard of hearing.']
Description: Dogs For Better Lives provides trained hearing dogs to people who are deaf or hard of hearing, to alert them of household sounds that are necessary for everyday safety and independence. Through sound awareness and companionship, these dogs provide greatly increased freedom.Services include:- Hearing dog placement- Continued training for dog and owner- Follow-up support for the life of the teamHearing Dog capabilities include:- Provides sound awareness at home, such as the smoke alarm, door knock, doorbell, phone, alarm clock, oven timer, name call, and a baby cry- Provides increased awareness when out in public, such as a siren, honking horn, name call- Helps ease anxiety sometimes experienced in social situations- Companionship- Reduces feeling of isolation often faced by people with hearing lossThere is no application fee or deposit required for this program. If you are considering applying for one of our professionally trained dogs, please complete the pre-screening questionnaire on our website. There is an in-home interview of an applicant's household required as part of the screening process. The waiting period for a Hearing Dog is approximately 12 months from the time the person is accepted to receive a Hearing Dog.
Coverage: This program covers residents of All 50 states.

Service_name: Warrior Service Dog Training (TADSAW – Train a Dog Save a Warrior)
Eligibility: ['Serves wounded Veteran ServiceMembers (Active Duty, Retired, Discharged), surviving with Military Induced Anxiety Depression Syndrome (MIADS), Post Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD), Military Sexual Trauma (MST) and/or Traumatic Brain Injury (TBI).']
Description: The Train a Dog Save a Warrior  (TADSAW) program serves the veteran, the family and the community, by providing the warrior with a K-9 rescue ‘Battle Buddy’ and the training and tools needed to become an accredited TADSAW Warrior/Service Dog Team at no charge to the Veteran or the family.Service provided:- Service dog training based on a 15 to 25 week course of Positive Reinforced trainingTADSAW combines the disciplines of occupational, physical, psychopharmaceutical and spiritual therapy in a single program in order to restore and improve the Veteran’s quality of life.  Contact us for additional information or to request an application. After your application has been received, the TADSAW trainer will evaluate your personal dog for viability, or an appropriate candidate from a shelter will be selected if you do not have a dog. We will try to locate trainers within a 60-90 minute driving radius of your home, if not closer.
Coverage: This program covers residents of All 50 states.

We have developed partnerships with other non-profit organizations that specialize in providing air and ground travel for those in need.
